author: parithosh
content: long tail of the problem is that its extremely hard to gain any confidence in the exact topology mainnet has and really diffucult to simulate things like load due to mempool/syncing as those are near random. So we can gain a decent chunk of confidence (see 4844 analysis), but then things like timing games/mempool load throw off most estimations we have. I guess we're only ever going to get a reasonable estimate from devnets, but we won't get the real thing until mainnet - meaning we always go with the safe value and never the bleeding edge.

author: pipermerriam
content: Lets be careful about vague definitions of what we are trying to support.  This is in push-back to the term "remote countries".  I think the goal here is to define real minimums in terms of uplink and downlink speeds that the protocol is aiming to support.  I don't think anyone is suggesting we support the most remote regions of the globe, only that we take into account what we are actually aiming to support and be eyes open about what regions that excludes.

author: francis.li
content:
I want to argue for a more open stance, especially for those complex networked systems, there will always be areas that we cannot fully simulate / test with devnets, no matter how much effort we put into them (if they're worth the effort at all).
Instead, maybe we can try to go with a combination of below techniques:
1. let's go with fast iterations, make blob increase easy and indepdent of hard forks, use real network data to inform our decisions
2. define a good set of network metrics to monitor, like reorg rate, impact on tx inclusion, etc, and run them periodically (weekly, daily, whatever)
3. and move forward if all metrics look good, rollback, if there's issues and then with real data, we can find what's the bottleneck and how to improve them

My worry with going with the safe choices and coupling blob increase with hard forks is that, the speed of increase will be too slow, and we're all constrained by that

author: tersec
content: How would this work in a decentralized way? There are blockchains which can coordinate this kind of change easily, but a strength/weakness of Ethereum is exactly that it consists of about a half-dozen each of CLs and ELs with varying release schedules and no uniform way of mass-applying configuration changes.

author: tersec
content: At least for Nimbus, we routinely run into people who update exactly once per hardfork, for example, and in theory that's all that's necessary.

author: potuz
content: The sort of metrics that can go wrong are slow to reflect and once they happen is hard to go back. If an increase leads to validator centralization, once that happens is irreversible. And such a trend it's very hard to measure on chain and even harder to attribute it to a single decision

author: potuz
content: In addition to another more mundane issue: one of my worries is not about the happy case but rather our adversarial resilience. If we're lucky we never need to test if we can resist a week of non finality on mainnet. But if we're not? One takes resilience for granted until it's actually needed. Goerli died and no one could save it even though we tried.
